#Text=Build a Model of a Swarm Robot
#Text=Interested in robotics and model-making ?
#Text=Follow these steps to build your own model of a swarm robot .
#Text=They may not demonstrate the kind of " swarm intelligence " you 'd hope to see in a real swarm robotics project , but it can be fun to put them together and watch them swarm around in a bunch .

column1: #Text=Steps
#Text=Making a Single Swarm Robot
#Text=Cut two 4 pieces of 16 - 24 gauge wire .
#Text=Any kind of wire you have available is fine .
#Text=Some options are using a wire hanger , annealed wire , galvanized , electrical copper wire , or even pipe cleaners .
#Text=Bend both wire pieces at the middle ; one shaped like a U and the other shaped like an M. These will be your swarm robot 's legs .
#Text=Cut a 1 inch by 2.5 inch thin piece of plastic , wood , or aluminum .
#Text=This will be the body of your swarm robot .
#Text=Get a small DC powered universal brush motor .
#Text=You can find them and salvage from small electrical toys , purchase online , or from your local hobby store .
#Text=They are some of the cheapest , most simple and easiest to power and run .
#Text=They can run from as little as 1.5 volts up to 12 volts depending on their size .
#Text=Solder one terminal of the motor to a 3 inch thin electrical wire .
#Text=For this build it wo n't matter which side you pick since universal motors run on either polarity ( + - ) or ( - + ) and current charge ( A/C . or D/C ) .
#Text=Solder a thin electrical wire to the other end of the motor .
#Text=If you 're able to find a small switch , solder one end of the switch terminal to one of the electrical wires on the motor .
#Text=This is an option if you want to turn on and off your robot without having to pull the cable , battery off .
#Text=Attach the motor to the body of the swarm robot with a hot glue gun .
#Text=Attach or glue a single blade propeller to the motor shaft .
#Text=This will cause the motor to run out of balance and shake and vibrate the entire frame of the robot .
#Text=Glue the wire legs to the body .
#Text=Tape one wire from the motor and the other end/switch ) to a AAA battery .
#Text=Turn the swarm robot on and place it down on a flat surface .
#Text=Watch it shake around and roll like a swarming ant or termite .
#Text=Making a Swarm of Robots
#Text=Find as many motors as you can and build a robot for each one .
#Text=Repeat the building process and connect all the robots in series .
#Text=Use a cell phone charger to power them all at once .
#Text=Making An advanced Swarm of Robots
#Text=Solder a Infrared receiver diode to a small Servomotor and an Electronic controlled board .
#Text=You can find these kind of boards from several open source Hardware and Open source Software available online to program each mini receiver boards to your Swarm Bots . .
#Text=You can find any size or power capacity of suitable motor for your Project .
#Text=Some surprisingly powerful miniature motors on cell phone or pager vibrators is a good way to Up-cycle all those old cell phones stashed in a box on the attic or garage .
#Text=Program each robot caring a E.S.C ( electronic Speed Controller ) with a E.S.C. programing card .
#Text=These kind of cards have adapters with fittings to the servo , Brush-less or stepper motors , a power source and a connection to a transmitter .
#Text=A programming card has a connection that fits the E.S.C's transmitter input adapter and a USB to program language and Code Instructions to the Swarm Bots .
#Text=Solder a set of color coded LCD 's to the board .
#Text=You can program your robots to light up a certain color and even behave or move for each different signals you 're able to program and command your swarm .
#Text=Solder an infrared transmitter the same way you connected and programmed an LCD .
#Text=Now each Swarm-Bot will be capable of communicating with any other robot near enough or within sight of the infrared .
#Text===
